President Trump leaving the door open

pressure for the Fed to cut interest
rates.

persistence there, Jonathan. And look, I
I do have access to the the number of
the night before, but when I'm coming on

uh Chair Powell. And as I've said, I'm

there are a lot of great candidates, and

has the chairman himself, the Fed chair

Marie, I think that'd be a judgment that
the Chinese indigenous uh manufacturers

if there's an equivalent chip, then the

it wasn't, but was it potentially to
make sure that you can get the licenses

would say is uh President Trump's able

been saying for a while that if

the deals that I thought were excellent

giving a green light to Trump to
President Trump to keep going to take
hardline approaches and to keep trying

Look, I I I think this this nar

the idea that some some market ups or

focused on is getting the best deals

think what the market's saying is
market's willing to look forward three,

a trigger point? Is there sort of a
sense at which it it acts as a gut check
and sort of pulls back some of the
negotiating tactics?
Look, I I I think that the market
understands what we're doing. Sometimes
individual market people don't.
Sometimes the television personalities
don't. But you know, good good thing
about President Trump is he always tells
you what he wants and what he wants is
fair trade here.

my colleagues around the table, Mr.
Treasury Secretary, but you did tell me

was the ceiling when it comes to those
rates. But since then, we have actually
had some tariff rates. the president
announced in letters higher than those
rates he announced on that big chart on

ceiling when it comes to tariff rates

partners?
Uh I I think that uh I I said if they if
they come and they negotiate in good
faith then those are ceilings and uh
some some of the talks got off to a very
slow start.
So who's negotiating good faith at this
moment? who's not
again I congratulated the UK the other
day as I told many of our trading
partners and and Marie I may have said
on that day or a few days after April
2nd I'd advise countries to move quickly
because with President Trump the first
deals are usually the best deals and and
the UK came in early they got a great
deal and everybody else is kind of
dragging right now. Well, when it comes
to uh Japan, you're headed there at the
end of this week. Do you expect to come
back with a deal?
Uh I'm going to Japan to represent uh
the United States government and the
American people at the international
expo, which we used to know as the
World's Fair. So, this coming Saturday
is going to be America's Day, and I'll
be taking a delegation includes the
labor secretary, deputy secretary of
state, will be representing the US. So
th this is a celebration of the US more
than trade talks.
Mr. Secretary, before you go, just a
final question. I'm embarrassed to say
that my knowledge of college basketball
is nothing like yours, but I can tell
you back in the '90s in English
football, there used to be a concept of
player managers. There used to be

also put themselves on the field and
they play too. Effectively, they had two
jobs. And I'm wondering from your
perspective whether that's something
you'd be interested in. We've seen that
throughout the administration. Is that
something you think that you could
pursue? both the Treasury Secretary and
the Fed chair.
Uh, look, I I I think I have the best
job in town. Uh, I will do what
President Trump wants. We got a lot of
great Fed candidates and um, you know, I
I'm confident it's going to be a robust
process. Jonathan,
has he asked you?
What's that?
Has he asked you? Are you part of the
process?
Uh, I I am part of the decision-making
process, but again, it's the fin final
decision is going to be President
Trump's.
Mr. Secretary, appreciate your time.
Thank you. the Treasury Secretary there,
Scott Besson, on a range of issues,
including trade and the future of this
Federal Reserve.
